title: 111_s788
content: The "m-SPAM Act of 2009" exempts certain qualifying messages from being classified as mobile service commercial messages. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 is amended to define "commercial mobile service" and "mobile service commercial message" as related to electronic mail messages sent to wireless devices. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 defines commercial mobile service and mobile service commercial message for electronic mail messages sent to wireless devices. The Act allows recipients to opt-in to receive commercial messages and excludes messages related to facilitating transactions, providing warranty information, or maintaining ongoing commercial relationships. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows recipients to opt-in to receive commercial messages for ongoing commercial relationships, including notices of changes in terms, status, and regular account balance information. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows recipients to receive messages related to ongoing commercial relationships, employment benefits, and transactions they have agreed to. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows for the sending of short messages between wireless devices and mobile service commercial messages under certain conditions. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows providers of commercial mobile service to send commercial messages to subscribers at no charge, unless the subscriber has opted out. Amendments were made to ensure compliance with the Act. Prohibition on unauthorized mobile service commercial messages containing unsolicited advertisements. Prohibition on unauthorized mobile service commercial messages containing unsolicited advertisements. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit sending commercial messages to individuals without their prior authorization. Definitions are also updated to align with existing regulations. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit unauthorized mobile service commercial messages. The amendment clarifies that certain types of messages, such as those sent between wireless devices or from a provider to its subscribers at no charge, are not prohibited. Subscribers can opt out of receiving such messages from the provider. The Act prohibits unauthorized mobile service commercial messages, but certain types of messages are exempt. Subscribers can opt out of receiving messages from the provider. State law authority remains unchanged compared to commercial electronic mail messages under the CAN-SPAM Act of 2003. SEC. 4 explicitly prohibits unsolicited advertisements in mobile service commercial messages sent to cellular telephones. The Federal Trade Commission will revise the do-not-call registry provisions to prohibit sending mobile service commercial messages to numbers on the registry, except for messages sent by the provider at no cost to the subscriber. The Federal Trade Commission will update the do-not-call registry rules to ban sending commercial mobile service messages to numbers on the registry, except for messages sent by the provider at no cost to the subscriber. The term "commercial mobile service" is defined in the Communications Act of 1934.
